title: Redesign tool call UI to be flat wall-to-wall with dark green background
description: Change the tool call UI design from the current button/card style to a flat, wall-to-wall design that stretches from edge to edge. Requirements: 1) Remove rounded corners (use square corners), 2) Use flat dark green background color, 3) Stretch full width (wall-to-wall, not constrained like a button), 4) No shadow or elevation effects, 5) Keep collapsible functionality. This will make tool calls visually distinct from chat messages while maintaining a clean, flat design aesthetic. Related: ChatView.tsx tool call rendering, Collapsible component styling.

title: Fix MCP OAuth refresh token scope mismatch error
description: When refreshing expired OAuth tokens, the token refresh fails with 400 error: 'cannot request scope `mcp.e-gineering.com/mcp:access` not provided by refresh token'. The refresh token request is including the original scope parameter, but OAuth 2.1 spec says refresh tokens should not include scope unless requesting a narrower scope. Need to investigate if we should: 1) Remove scope from refresh requests entirely, 2) Only include scope if explicitly narrowing permissions, or 3) Store the original scope from the refresh token and use that instead of the authorization scope.

title: Make tool call display full width with green background
description: Tool calls should be displayed full width instead of in constrained bubbles. Apply a subtle green background (not too bright) to visually distinguish them from regular messages. Ensure they remain collapsible. Related components: ChatView.tsx (ToolCall rendering section), may need to update Collapsible styling and Card overrides.

title: Debug conversation title summarization not working
description: Title summarization is falling back to raw text (first 5 words) instead of AI-generated summaries. Root cause: Silent failures when API key is missing prevent fallback execution. AI generation errors are being caught and fallback works, but missing API key returns early. See analysis in conversationStorage.ts:290-431. Fix: Ensure fallback always executes regardless of API key availability.
close_reason: Fixed silent failures - API key errors now trigger fallback. User should check browser console for [Title Generation] logs to debug remaining issues.

title: Make assistant response display full width without chat bubble
description: Currently assistant messages are displayed in chat bubbles (Card components with rounded corners and backgrounds). Change to a full-width, flat interface to better display markdown tables and other formatted content. This should improve readability for code blocks, tables, and long-form responses. Related components: ChatView.tsx (Response component), possibly need to update the message rendering logic.

title: Research conversation history sync across devices for iOS
description: Research how to sync conversation history across user's iOS devices (iPhone, iPad) for Capacitor apps. Current implementation stores conversations locally using Capacitor Preferences, which doesn't sync across devices. Need to investigate: 1) iCloud storage options for Capacitor apps (iCloud Drive, CloudKit, NSUbiquitousKeyValueStore), 2) Available Capacitor plugins for iCloud storage or sync, 3) Native iOS CloudKit APIs and how to integrate with Capacitor, 4) Best practices for syncing large conversation datasets (messages with tool calls, attachments), 5) Conflict resolution strategies when conversations are modified on multiple devices, 6) Performance implications of sync operations, 7) User privacy considerations and iCloud storage quotas, 8) Migration path from local Preferences to synced storage. The goal is to provide seamless conversation history across all user devices while maintaining performance and respecting storage limits.

title: Investigate changing color of green UI elements
description: Review and potentially change the green color used in various UI elements throughout the app. Need to investigate: 1) All locations where green colors are used (buttons, indicators, accents, etc.), 2) Current green color values (Tailwind classes like bg-green-500, text-green-600, etc.), 3) Alternative color options that maintain good contrast and accessibility, 4) Whether this affects theme consistency across light/dark modes, 5) User feedback or design rationale for color change. title: Implement A2A client support (connect to external agents)
description:
# A2A Client Implementation

## Vision

Make caw caw an **A2A client** (in addition to being an MCP client), enabling users to connect to external specialized AI agents.

**Architecture Pattern:**
- **MCP Client** ‚Üí Connect to external tools (currently implemented ‚úì)
- **A2A Client** ‚Üí Connect to external agents (to be implemented)

## Use Case

User can connect to specialized A2A agents (e.g., code specialist, research specialist, data analysis specialist) and delegate tasks mid-conversation, similar to how they currently use MCP tools.

Example: "Use the code analysis agent at https://example.com/.well-known/agent.json to review this code"

## Prior Research

Previous research completed in **cawcaw-dks** (Dec 4, 2025):
- Comprehensive A2A protocol research documented in `history/a2a-research-2025-12-04.md`
- Identified `a2a-ai-provider` npm package (alpha status)
- Google Codelabs demo agents available for testing
- Protocol uses agent cards at `.well-known/agent.json`

## Technical Approach

### Option: Use `a2a-ai-provider`

**Package**: `a2a-ai-provider` by DracoBlue (alpha)
**Integration**: Works with AI SDK v5 using `generateText`/`streamText`

**Implementation pattern** (similar to web_search tool):
```typescript
import { a2a } from 'a2a-ai-provider';
import { generateText } from 'ai';

const result = await generateText({
  model: a2a('https://agent.example.com/.well-known/agent-card.json'),
  messages,
  providerOptions: {
    a2a: { contextId: conversationId }
  },
});
```

## Implementation Plan

### Phase 1: Basic A2A Client
1. Install `a2a-ai-provider`
2. Add A2A agent configuration to Settings UI (new section similar to MCP servers)
3. User can add agent card URLs
4. Test with Google Codelabs demo agents (burger/pizza sellers)

### Phase 2: Agent Discovery
1. Fetch and parse agent cards (`.well-known/agent.json`)
2. Display agent capabilities in UI
3. Auto-discover agent metadata (name, description, skills)

### Phase 3: Integration
1. Make A2A agents available as delegable resources (like MCP tools)
2. AI can choose to delegate to A2A agents mid-conversation
3. Show which agent is responding in UI

## UI/UX Considerations

1. **Settings ‚Üí A2A Agents** (new tab/section)
   - Add agent card URL
   - Display agent metadata
   - Connection status indicator

2. **Chat Interface**
   - Visual indicator when A2A agent is responding
   - Agent attribution ("Response from Code Analysis Agent")

3. **Storage**
   - Store agent configurations in Capacitor Secure Storage
   - Key: `a2a_agent_configs`

## Risks & Limitations

‚ö†Ô∏è **Alpha Status**: `a2a-ai-provider` is not production-ready
- Consider experimental/beta feature flag
- Clear warning in UI about alpha status

**Mitigations:**
- Implement as optional feature (disabled by default)
- Wait for package to reach beta/stable before enabling by default
- Monitor Vercel AI SDK issue #7442 for official support

## Testing Resources

- **Google Codelabs**: Burger/pizza seller demo agents
- **A2A Inspector**: Web-based testing tool
- **a2a-samples**: GitHub repo with examples

## Success Criteria

- [ ] User can add A2A agent URLs in Settings
- [ ] Agent card is fetched and metadata displayed
- [ ] AI can delegate to configured A2A agents
- [ ] Responses from A2A agents are properly attributed in UI
- [ ] Works with both OpenAI and Anthropic chat providers

## References

- Prior research: cawcaw-dks (Dec 4, 2025)
- Research document: `history/a2a-research-2025-12-04.md`
- A2A Protocol: https://a2a-protocol.org/latest/
- Community provider: https://github.com/DracoBlue/a2a-ai-provider
- Vercel tracking: https://github.com/vercel/ai/discussions/6639

title: Support both OpenAI and Anthropic keys at startup
description:
# Startup Token UX Issue ## Current Problem The app's startup screen (ChatView.tsx:1062-1093) has OpenAI-specific messaging that doesn't support Anthropic users: ### Issue 1: OpenAI-Only Messaging (line 1069) ```typescript

Enter your OpenAI API key to get started

``` **Problem**: Only mentions OpenAI, ignoring Anthropic users entirely. ### Issue 2: OpenAI-Only Key Storage The `saveApiKey` function (lines 363-371) only saves to `openai_api_key`: ```typescript const saveApiKey = async () => { if (tempApiKey.trim()) { try { await SecureStoragePlugin.set({ key: 'openai_api_key', value: tempApiKey }); setApiKey(tempApiKey); setShowApiKeyInput(false); } catch (error) { console.error('Failed to save API key:', error); } } }; ``` **Problem**: Doesn't recognize or save Anthropic API keys. Users must go to Settings after startup to add Anthropic keys. ## User Impact 1. Anthropic users are confused at startup ("Why does it only ask for OpenAI key?") 2. No indication that the app supports both providers at first launch 3. Extra friction: must dismiss startup screen, open Settings, add Anthropic key 4. Poor first-run experience for Anthropic users ## Proposed Solution ### Option A: Multi-Provider Startup Screen (Recommended) Update the startup screen to support both providers: 1. **Add provider selection**: Tabs or toggle for "OpenAI" vs "Anthropic" 2. **Update messaging**: "Enter your API key to get started" 3. **Key format validation**: - OpenAI keys start with `sk-` - Anthropic keys start with `sk-ant-` - Show hint based on selected provider 4. **Update saveApiKey**: Save to correct storage key based on provider selection ### Option B: Dual Input (Alternative) Show both input fields at startup: - "OpenAI API Key (optional)" - "Anthropic API Key (optional)" - Require at least one key to proceed ### Option C: Smart Detection (Alternative) Single input with automatic key type detection: - Detect provider based on key prefix (`sk-` vs `sk-ant-`) - Save to appropriate storage key - Generic messaging: "Enter your API key" ## Recommended Implementation: Option A **Reason**: Most explicit, clear for users, matches the Settings tab pattern. ## Implementation Checklist - [ ] Add provider selection UI to startup screen (tabs or toggle) - [ ] Update prompt text to be provider-agnostic - [ ] Update placeholder text based on selected provider - [ ] Modify `saveApiKey` to save to correct storage key - [ ] Add key format validation (optional but helpful) - [ ] Update "Save API Key" button logic to handle both providers - [ ] Test both OpenAI and Anthropic first-run experiences ## File to Modify `src/components/ChatView.tsx`: - Lines 1062-1093 (startup UI) - Lines 363-371 (saveApiKey function)

title: Research agent-to-agent (A2A) communication patterns
description:
# A2A Research Findings

## Key Distinction: MCP vs A2A

**Critical understanding**: MCP (Model Context Protocol) and A2A (Agent-to-Agent) serve different purposes:
- **MCP**: Agent-to-tool integration (what caw caw already has) - connects AI to external tools/APIs via JSON-RPC 2.0
- **A2A**: Agent-to-agent communication - enables multiple AI agents to collaborate and communicate with each other

## Multi-Agent Workflow Patterns (Vercel AI SDK)

The AI SDK supports 4 core multi-agent patterns:

1. **Sequential Workflow**: Agents execute tasks in order, passing results to next agent
2. **Parallel Execution**: Multiple agents work simultaneously on independent tasks
3. **Routing**: Director agent routes tasks to specialized agents based on context
4. **Orchestrator**: Supervisor agent coordinates multiple sub-agents with feedback loops

## Implementation Options for caw caw

### Option 1: AI SDK Built-in Multi-Agent Support
**Approach**: Use Vercel AI SDK's native multi-agent workflow capabilities

**Pros**:
- Already using AI SDK - no new dependencies
- Native TypeScript support
- Works with both OpenAI and Anthropic providers
- Lightweight, runs client-side in browser/mobile
- Patterns: sequential, parallel, routing, orchestrator

**Cons**:
- Limited documentation (newer feature)
- Need to implement orchestration logic ourselves
- No pre-built agent templates

**Best for**: Lightweight multi-agent workflows within single chat session

### Option 2: Microsoft Agent Framework (AutoGen + Semantic Kernel)
**Approach**: Integrate AutoGen's multi-agent conversation patterns

**Pros**:
- Mature framework with proven patterns
- Built-in conversation management
- Supports various agent roles (assistant, executor, critic)
- Strong multi-agent coordination

**Cons**:
- Python-first (would need JS/TS port or API wrapper)
- Heavy dependency for mobile app
- May require backend service
- Overkill for simple use cases

**Best for**: Complex enterprise multi-agent systems

### Option 3: OpenAI Agents SDK
**Approach**: Use OpenAI's official multi-agent SDK

**Pros**:
- Official OpenAI support
- Native multi-agent patterns
- TypeScript/JavaScript support

**Cons**:
- OpenAI-only (wouldn't work with Anthropic)
- New SDK (less mature than alternatives)
- May require OpenAI-specific features

**Best for**: OpenAI-exclusive workflows

### Option 4: Custom Orchestration Layer
**Approach**: Build lightweight orchestrator on top of existing AI SDK integration

**Pros**:
- Full control over behavior
- Minimal dependencies
- Optimized for caw caw's specific needs
- Works with all providers

**Cons**:
- Need to build and maintain orchestration logic
- More development effort upfront
- Risk of reinventing wheels

**Best for**: Highly customized workflows specific to caw caw

## Architectural Considerations

1. **Client-side vs Backend**: caw caw runs client-side with no backend - limits framework options
2. **Mobile Constraints**: Capacitor mobile app needs lightweight solutions
3. **Multi-Provider Support**: Must work with both OpenAI and Anthropic
4. **MCP Integration**: A2A should complement existing MCP tool integration, not replace it

## Recommendation: Hybrid Approach

**Phase 1** (Low effort, immediate value):
- Implement **AI SDK sequential workflow** pattern for simple multi-step tasks
- Example: Research agent ‚Üí Writing agent ‚Üí Review agent pipeline
- Use existing AI SDK, minimal new code

**Phase 2** (Future enhancement):
- Add **routing pattern** for specialized agent delegation
- Example: User asks question ‚Üí Director routes to appropriate specialist (code, writing, research)

**Phase 3** (Advanced):
- Implement **orchestrator pattern** for complex multi-agent collaboration
- Feedback loops, agent-to-agent communication
- Consider backend service if needed for complex orchestration

## Next Steps

1. Prototype sequential workflow with AI SDK (2-3 agents in pipeline)
2. Test with both OpenAI and Anthropic providers
3. Design UX for multi-agent conversations (show which agent is speaking)
4. Evaluate if custom orchestrator needed or AI SDK patterns sufficient
close_reason: Research completed with comprehensive findings documented: MCP vs A2A distinction clarified, 4 implementation options analyzed with pros/cons, phased recommendation provided
